name: pipe-organ
definition: An instrument consisting of a number of pipes that sound tones when supplied with air and a keyboard that operates a mechanism controlling the flow of air to the pipes.
description:
The pipe organ is a musical instrument that produces sound by driving pressurized air through organ pipes selected via a keyboard.

Pipes can only play one note. They are made of metal or wood and the longer the pipe the lower the pitch.

Because each pipe produces a single pitch, the pipes are provided in sets called ranks, each of which has a common timbre and volume throughout the keyboard compass.

Reed pipes in a pipe organ produce sound via the reed beating - similar to other wind instruments like saxophones or clarinets.

The sound volume and timbre that is produced in the pipes is controlled by the amount of air supplied to the pipe and the pipe's construction.

A pipe organ has one or more keyboards played by the hands and a pedalboard played by the feet.

A musician that plays the pipe organ is referred to as an organist.

facts.name: Some organs have several keyboards
facts.value: Some organs have several keyboards - and it is not uncommon for large organs to have five. Keyboards are referred to as 'manuals'.

facts.name: The largest church pipe organ in the world
facts.value: The largest church pipe organ in the world is located in Los Angeles at the First Congressional Church. The largest church organ in Europe is in Germany's Passau Cathedral.

facts.name: Flue pipes produce sound when air is forced through a fipple
facts.value: Flue pipes in a pipe organ produce sound when air is forced through a fipple - similar to a wind instrument such as a recorder.

facts.name: The pipes of a pipe organ are lined up in rows
facts.value: The pipes of a pipe organ are lined up in rows and can occupy a very large amount of space. The organ case that holds the pipes can be as large as a room.

facts.name: Pipes are arranged into ranks
facts.value: Pipes are arranged into ranks - which means they are grouped together to enable similarly shaped pipes (and those made of similar materials) can be played together.

facts.name: The lower manual is referred to as the 'Great'
facts.value: The lower manual is referred to as the 'Great' and the highest manual is referred to as the 'Swell'.

facts.name: The foot pedals are arranged like a keyboard
facts.value: The foot pedals are arranged like a keyboard. Organists must learn to play the foot pedals without looking down.

facts.name: Were commonly used to provide sound to silent films
facts.value: During the silent film era pipe organs were commonly found in theatres to accompany the film.

facts.name: The oldest pipe organ in existence today
facts.value: The oldest pipe organ in existence today is believed to be the one in Sion, Switzerland, at the Basilica of Valere, built in 1390.

facts.name: Pipe organs are made with at least one set of pipes
facts.value: Pipe organs are made with at least one set of pipes, and at least one keyboard. Sound is produced when pressurized air passes through the pipes.

facts.name: Very large organs were built in Britain's gothic cathedrals
facts.value: Very large organs were built in Britain's gothic cathedrals in the Middle Ages.

facts.name: Metal pipes are usually made of alloy
facts.value: Pipes made of metal are usually made of a mixture of metals called an 'alloy'. Common metals in the alloy include lead and tin, although some are made of silver, and brass.
